comments.content:
No Yes Yes
The probe is used to determine if backend instance is ok. If the page is gone, lb will consider VM2 to be dead
if you delete the page1.html then health probe will fail, and then all requests will be sent to VM1, isnt this correct?

discussion.content:
1. If users served page1.htm from VM1, the user refreshes the web browser, page1.htm will be refreshed from VM1 always. Y/N
No b/c session persistence is set to none.
2. If you change the protocol of rule 1, all web requests will fail.Y/N
Yes - web requests use HTTP protocol, not TCP.
3. If you delete probe1.htm from VM2, LB1 will route all web requests to VM1. Y/N
No - LB offers health probes w/ load-bal rules. Health probe config & probe responds deter which bkend pool instance will rcv new flows. Use health probes to detect app faliure on bkend instance. Create a custom response to a health probe & use health probe to control flow and manage load or planned downtime. When health probes fail, load bal stops sending new flows to unhealthy instance. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/load-balancer/load-balancer-custom-probe-overview

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You have an Azure subscription named Subscription1 that contains the resources in the following table.
//IMG//


A web server runs on VM1 and VM2.
When you request a webpage named Page1.htm from the Internet, LB1 balances the web requests to VM1 and VM2, and you receive a response.
On LB1, you have a rule named Rule1 as shown in the Rule1 exhibit. (Click the Exhibit tab.)
//IMG//

You have a health probe named Probe1 as shown in the Probe1 exhibit. (Click the Exhibit tab.)
//IMG//

For each of the following statements, select Yes if the statement is true. Otherwise, select No.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:

You have 100 Azure subscriptions. All the subscriptions are associated to the same Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.com.
You are a global administrator.
You plan to create a report that lists all the resources across all the subscriptions.
You need to ensure that you can view all the resources in all the subscriptions.
What should you do?
questions.answer_description:
The New-AzureADUserAppRoleAssignment cmdlet assigns a user to an application role in Azure Active Directory (AD). Use it for the application report.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/azuread/new-azureaduserapproleassignment?view=azureadps-2.0

comments.content: Correct beacuse New-AzureADUserAppRoleAssignment is specific to Azure AD Role which Assigns a user to an application role. Here we need RBAC role on all 100 subscriptions.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
For testing purposes, the correct answer is D.

choices.A: From the Azure portal, modify the profile settings of your account.
choices.B: From Windows PowerShell, run the Add-AzureADAdministrativeUnitMember cmdlet.
choices.C: From Windows PowerShell, run the New-AzureADUserAppRoleAssignment cmdlet.
choices.D: From the Azure portal, modify the properties of the Azure AD tenant.

questions.question_text:
Your company has an Azure subscription named Subscription1.
The on-premises network contains the physical servers shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You plan to use Azure Site Recovery to migrate the on-premises servers to Subscription1.
You need to identify which servers can be migrated.
Which two servers should you identify? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
On main landing page referenced: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/vmware-physical-azure-support-matrix it shows 2008 SP1
Windows Server 2008 R2 with SP1 onwards. Supported.

There is this link here that indicates 2008 Server Core is not supported https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/migrate-tutorial-windows-server-2008

On the

Support for 8TB was made available in 2019, so is this question out of date? Or is there another reason that server 4 isn't right as well?

https://azure.microsoft.com/en-ca/updates/site-recovery-large-disks-8tb/
B is correct you need to view activity log in Subscriptions

Note: This question is part of a series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
You have an Azure subscription named Subscription1. Subscription1 contains a resource group named RG1. RG1 contains resources that were deployed by using templates.
You need to view the date and time when the resources were created in RG1.
Solution: From the Subscriptions blade, you select the subscription, and then click Programmatic deployment.
Does this meet the goal?
